title: Riot really do their job on keep toxic players out of games?
body:
I wander how many players get banned out of players being reported? I don't see many difference on this due to there are many toxic players still in game. Also, I can still meet toxic players who I marked as bad toxic players and reported before. And, of course, they are doing toxic shit again. 

WHY THE HELL this happens all the time? maybe players can discuss about it and wait RIOT to "FIND" an excuse to solve this issue instead of doing job properly.

replies.body:
Banning people = lose money

Riot wants to make money!

FACTS

Riot knows this, the mods know this, it's all about the money!

If I tell you that Riot employees are decent people like the rest of us, you wont believe me.

_So lets frame this in terms of profit:_

+ **Riot Games** business just like any other and they need profits to keep operating. We both agree on this.

 _**But what happens when one toxic player makes more than two players leave???**_
 
 ** 1 x (Toxic Player's money) â‰  (2+) x (Positive Player's money)**
 
   Now the equation doesn't balance!!! It's more profitable to ban the toxic player, and keep the positive players in-game.
 
> That's why Riot actually wants to ban people. Each toxic player in the game makes people leave and causes players to play less. This has a negative effect on profits.  Less people buy skins, less people buy RP and less people tell their friends about the game.

__*

So there you go. It definitely is all about the profit and that exactly why it's in **Riot**'s best interests to try to fix toxicity.

>If I tell you that Riot employees are decent people like the rest of us, you wont believe me.

I will believe that, that doesn't mean the system works, or is actually designed to take out every toxic player.
Whether the system is working up to standard is definitely up for debate. But saying that **Riot** is doing nothing or don't care at all, is simply not true.

>But saying that Riot is doing nothing or don't care at all

I'm not saying that they don't care, but they aren't doing anything to actually curb the toxicity.

I don't know if you're aware, but fixing toxicity isn't as easy as just banning a few toxic players.

> + In fact, the most toxic **8%** of the community is only responsible for **13%** of toxicity overall. It's actually neutral and positive players who make up the remaining **87%** of all toxicity. - [Source.](https://youtu.be/nbYQ0AVVBGU?t=4m34s)

This doesn't mean everyone is toxic. It means that once a week a positive player might have a game that's not up to standard with their usual behaviour. They might step out of line very infrequently, but it adds up. _This is a very difficult problem to solve._

**So what is Riot doing?**

1. The instant feedback system isn't ideal for banning toxic players. It was designed to reform players and give small punishments to good players who were just getting it a bit wrong. That's why it uses a 4 tier incremental system, rather than just instantly banning players.

 This was implemented a while ago but it's still working today and punishing players as we speak.

2. There is also a focus on extremely toxic players. [Manual audits](https://www.reddit.com/r/leagueoflegends/comments/4ol8no/riot_banning_toxic_players_faster/) are used on repeat offenders and extremely toxic behaviour. 

3. **The tribunal is being developed right now.** [Lyte](https://www.reddit.com/r/leagueoflegends/comments/3suitx/riot_lyte_on_the_status_of_the_tribunal/) said that the design for the tribunal was finalized, and [Riot Slumber Jack](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/mEIlagLk-when-is-the-tribunal-coming-back?comment=0006) confirmed that it will begin production after the new champion select (now finished).

4. The player behavior team is also responsible /remake and designing the new champion select, with the aim of reducing arguments and making the game more enjoyable.

The player behaviour team does a lot for us, but for some reason the community doesn't really even appreciate the gesture.

I challenge you to find a game which has more systems than League to fight toxicity.

The problem here is your wording, i'm not saying riot want's to keep the toxicity, no logical person want's this game to be toxic, it's just not a viable business strategy to actually stop toxicity, so what do riot do instead?

Why use realistic numbers, when you can use the numbers to show whatever you want?

Like if you look at a lot of what Riot does, it shows an unwillingness to actually stop toxicity, unless it works by you getting a small chat ban and you learning your lesson.

Hell even the whole "X% of players don't reoffend once they are punished" no that's horse shit, they just either avoid doing it in the dramatic way they were doing it, or don't get looked at, because riot will lose a customer if they keep banning someone.

>In fact, the most toxic 8% of the community is only responsible for 13% of toxicity overall. It's actually neutral and positive players who make up the remaining 87% of all toxicity.

What no one outside of whoever made these numbers up knows, is what constitutes a "good" player, and what counts as "toxicity" likelihood is Lyte has just gone ahead and enabled seeing every single report made, does that make all the reports valid?

Fact is these numbers are useless, and being used as propaganda to say "we are good" when really, there is no proof these numbers meaning anything useful.
